facts: The word “music” comes from the Greek word mousike, meaning the art of the Muses, who were thought to inspire creativity.
A “beat” is the steady pulse you tap your foot to, while “rhythm” is the pattern of long and short sounds that fits on top of the beat.
An octave happens when a note’s sound wave vibrates at exactly twice the frequency of another note, which is why the two notes sound closely related.
The modern piano can play very soft or very loud because its hammers hit the strings harder or softer depending on how you press the keys.
A symphony is a long musical work for an orchestra, usually split into several movements that each have a different speed or mood.
Jazz music grew in the United States by blending African rhythms, blues, and European instruments, and it often features improvisation, which means making music on the spot.
In many songs, a major key often sounds bright or happy and a minor key often sounds sad or serious, even though both can be used in many different moods.
